ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Elementary knowledge of Akkadian grammar and some history/literature.
A good foundation of the vocabulary and grammar of Akkadian, as well as being able to recognize some of the cuneiform signs.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course is very comprehensive, but the pace was just too fast for me.

The course was highly organized and each topic was introduced properly. I also appreciate how we were able to rely on Professor Koubkova's teaching of the material and that the textbook was only used as a supplement, which made it easier to learn. Professor Koubkova was intimately familiar with the language, and it was evident that she had studied it extensively.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If the student is very interested in ancient history and especially in ancient languages, yes. It's a unique opportunity to learn a little known language.
Yes, the vast majority of colleges and universities do not offer Akkadian, so Yale students who are interested in the ancient world should consider taking advantage of this special opportunity.
